all_paragraphs: Lately, I had to design a simple coding exercise to help pure beginners take their first steps on Python and feel the “Machine Learning fever”. Today, I am happy to share it with anyone interested to start exploring this field.
And if you ever find yourself stuck with the code, the complete notebook is stored here.
Like for every journey, you will need a proper vehicle to navigate towards your first model.
My advice would be to start with an on-line Python environment like Google Colab.
This will save you from installing Python on your computer or managing libraries (deciding to switch to Pandas 1.0 or the last Scikit-Learn release is probably not your main concern at this time !).
Once connected to Google Colab, just create a new Python notebook:
Note: each notebook you create will be stored in a dedicated folder on your Google Drive: Colab Notebooks.
Let’s rename your first notebook by clicking on its title:
You have to type the code below in the first cell and execute it thanks to the “play” button on the left (alternatively, you can press “Shift+Enter” keys).
Note: the first execution might take some time as Google Colab will connect to a dedicated cloud resource and create your environment.
I have prepared a simple dataset of 5000 lines, available here, combining 15 process parameters, measured every hour and the corresponding product quality: Premium, Approved, or Rejected.
We intend to build a model that will identify patterns leading to different quality types.

To load this CSV file into your coding environment, you need to open the “Files” interface (just click on the folder icon in the left panel) and drag the “classification_5000.csv” file below the sample files already stored.
Important: files are stored temporarily and might be removed once your session is closed.
Should you need to keep files permanently, you can connect your notebook to your Google Drive account (third icon in the “Files” panel).
Now that the “classification_5000.csv” file is part of your environment, let’s read it with the dedicated Python library: Pandas.

Note: you should consider Python as an (almost) empty shell when it is initiated, with only basic functions available so every time you need to perform specific tasks, you have to import the corresponding library.
In that case, we could execute “import pandas” (beware: Python instructions are case sensitive!) but “import pandas as pd” will allow us to call Pandas by its alias “pd” (shorter and quicker 😀).
We call the function that reads CSV files by using “pandas.read_csv” or “pd.read_csv”. This corresponds to the “library.function” scheme where the function is extracted from the library.
The “read_csv” function returns a “DataFrame” (i.e. tabular data) that we store into the “df” variable (see code below).
Pandas library provides numerous functions; let’s explore the most useful ones for beginners.
As mentioned previously, Python is an object-oriented language and we can call specific methods or properties corresponding to the type of object we manipulate. For example:
For this first example, the “read_csv” function has returned a DataFrame object which benefits from a lot of inherited and dedicated properties or methods: .shape, .info(), .describe(), .mean(), etc.
df.info() will provide the basic information regarding the DataFrame: the number of entries, the index type, the columns’ names, types, and non-null count or memory usage:

df.describe() will provide some elementary statistics regarding numerical features (you can notice that “DateTime” and “Quality” columns are not displayed): the number of entries, mean, standard deviation, min, max, and quartiles:
df.corr() will display the correlation matrix of all numerical features:
There are many more functions available: head(), sample(), tail(), merge(), concat(), etc. and you should explore a few in your notebook.
My only advice is that before trying to create a data processing function on your own, always check that the corresponding tool does not already exist.

One of the basic requirements to properly build a machine learning model is to train the algorithm on a large part of the dataset (from 70 to 90%) and then to perform tests regarding its robustness on the remaining unseen percents.
This process checks that the algorithm has not been subject to “overfitting”, which can be considered as learning all training cases by heart and miserably failing to make predictions on unseen data.
To randomly create this split, we call the dedicated “train_test_split” function from the SciKit-Learn library:
But before using this new function, we need to separate features (Xs) and the target (Y). We also remove the “DateTime” column, useless for this specific example.
Using the “.shape” property on every dataset created, we see that the number of lines is correct: “X_train” has 4000 rows (80% of the 5000 initial rows) and the same goes for “y_train”.
This is because “X_train” and “X_test” are Pandas DataFrames whereas “y_train” and “y_test” are Pandas Series.
To keep it (relatively) simple: a “Series” is a single-column data structure and a “DataFrame” is a collection of Series. So there is no columns dimension in Series since there can be only one.
The data is now properly structured into Train and Test sets; we can import a Random Forest algorithm.

As our target is categorical (Premium, Approved, or Rejected), we choose a “Classifier”. In case we would work with a numerical target (i.e. predicting a value), we would opt for a “Regressor” but the syntax would be similar.
First, we create a “RandomForestClassifier()” object and use the corresponding method “.fit” to train the algorithm on the training data:

Some parameters used to build the model are displayed after the training: the number of estimators (aka “trees” = 100), the maximum depth (here “None”), the split criterion (here “Gini Index”), etc. These are called “hyperparameters”.
The “.score” method allows us to evaluate the accuracy of the model. It compares the predictions from the model (y’) based on the features provided (Xs) Vs the true target values (y):

We notice that the model reaches a 100% accuracy on the training dataset. This could be good news but we are probably facing an “overfitting” issue, meaning that the model performs perfectly on training data by learning predictions “by heart” and it will probably fail to reach the same level of accuracy on unseen data.
The score reached on Test data does confirm this assumption as we see a ~20% performance drop on accuracy.

Without going into too many details, fine-tuning the hyperparameters (number of estimators, etc.) and using cross-validation (shuffling several times the data while training the model) could prevent it from overfitting.
Let’s have a look at the differences between predictions and actual values (I have chosen a “random_state” that samples rows with numerous errors; changing its value would decrease their number):
Even if imperfect, our model still achieves an acceptable accuracy with an 80% success rate.
The question is: what are the features among the different process parameters which help the model predict the quality of the product?
The “.feature_importances_” property of the model provides this information but the array is not easy (euphemism😅) to interpret:
Let’s convert this array into a DataFrame to display it in a nicer way (the code is a little bit tricky, you have to trust me on that one):
Process parameters are ranked by their importance and we can consider that “Outside Temperature”, “Inside Pressure”, and “Color Density” play an active role in the predictions.
If you have reached this sentence, you have created and evaluated your first machine learning model 🙌
